journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Control design for a hypersonic aircraft using a switched linear parameter-varying system approach

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Engineering, University of Agder, Norway
2Research Institute of Intelligent Control and Systems, Harbin Institute of Technology, China
3Department of Computing and Mathematical Sciences, University of Glamorgan, UK

author-notes.corresp: Lixian Zhang, Research Institute of Intelligent Control and Systems, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China. Email: lixianzhang@hit.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: This paper is concerned with the control problem of an air-breathing hypersonic aircraft using a switched linear-parameter-varying systems approach. The rigid non-linear longitudinal model of a generic hypersonic aircraft is adopted with the aim of verifying the design methodology of the developed controller and switching logic. By linearizing the non-linear model of the hypersonic aircraft at trim points and dividing the velocity range into several parts, a switched linear parameter-varying model for the underlying system is derived. With the aid of multiple Lyapunov-like functions technique, controllers that ensure the tracking of given commands of the closed-loop system are designed under mode-independent and mode-dependent switching logic, respectively. Simulation results for the generic hypersonic aircraft show the effectiveness of the proposed method and the advantages of the mode-dependent switching logic.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Air-breathing hypersonic aircraft are receiving considerable amounts of attention due to their affordable access to space that is of interest both to the military and for high-speed civilian transportation.1 The control of hypersonic aircraft is very challenging, a result of the high complexity of their equations of motion that stems from strong couplings between the significant flexibility, large modelling uncertainty and the slender geometries required for the aircraft.2 The longitudinal dynamic equations derived by Schmidt3 and Chavez and David4 that include rigid and flexible models are widely utilized to overcome these impediments.5–7 In practice, for convenience, rigid longitudinal models are more frequently used to verify the control methodologies although they are highly simplified representations of the actual system.

Generally, the characterized dramatic parameter variations and wide velocity range of hypersonic aircraft render their stability and dynamic performance different from other aircraft. With such properties, hypersonic aircraft are sensitive to flight condition changes and it is difficult to measure and estimate their aerodynamic characteristics. Therefore, a highly integrated guidance scheme which can overcome these unfavourable conditions is required to perform a robust, high-performance flight.8 For such a purpose, numerous effective control strategies have been proposed in the recent literature. In terms of the flexible model, in Hughes,9 a full state feedback
H
∞
control method is proposed for the synthesis and simulation of the hypersonic aircraft with elastic effects. By constructing Lyapunov functions including the lower and upper bounds of the time-varying delay, a non-fragile controller is designed in Li et al.10 for the problem of reference tracking for a flexible air-breathing hypersonic aircraft with actuator delay and uncertainty. The problem of guaranteed cost control for a flexible air-breathing hypersonic aircraft is investigated in Li et al.11 In terms of rigid models, Wang and Stengel12 present a robust controller design with a dynamic inversion structure. The control law for a single-stage-to-orbit air-breathing hypersonic aircraft on an ascent accelerating path is formulated in Gregory et al.13 A computational tool to synthesize robust flight control for a longitudinal rigid model of a hypersonic vehicle is presented in Marrison and Stengel.14

The linear parameter-varying (LPV) approach has attracted considerable attention in the past decade.15 Recently, a class of LPV modelling and control methodologies for hypersonic aircraft have been developed to exploit the advantages of the LPV approach in coping with dramatic parameter variations and large flight range. For instance, Lind16 proposes a LPV framework, in which the structural dynamics are represented in terms of a set of state-space matrices that are affine functions of operating parameters. For the over-actuated issue, in Sigthorsson et al.,17 a controller design is given for a longitudinal LPV model of a hypersonic aircraft to enforce an ideal behaviour in the presence of redundant actuation. Moreover, with respect to large parameter variation and flight envelope, some papers that use switching-relevant techniques have also been reported in the literature, refer to Hughes.9 Recently, a switched LPV approach has also been proposed which has been used to create a satisfactory control performance for systems such as an F-16 aircraft,18 an active magnetic bearing system19 and a missile autopilot system.20 However, surprisingly, in the hypersonic aircraft regime, the utilization of the switched LPV technique has not been considered, which inspires the work in this paper. As far as the switching logic is concerned, the typical average dwell time (ADT) switching logic has been widely investigated21–27 and shown to be conservative since it ignores the specific properties of each subsystem, a new switching strategy called mode-dependent average dwell time (MDADT) in parallel with ADT but more flexible has been created in Zhao et al.28

This paper mainly addresses switched LPV system modelling and controller design for the rigid longitudinal dynamics of a hypersonic aircraft under the ADT and MDADT switching logics. The controller design method is presented such that the closed-loop system of the switched LPV system is stable with a pre-specified disturbance rejection index. Specifically, in the section ‘Switched LPV model for a hypersonic aircraft’ the detailed procedures to convert the non-linear system of the hypersonic aircraft into a switched LPV system are thoroughly demonstrated. In the first part of the section ‘Controller design approaches under ADT and MDADT switching logics’, some necessary preparations for further derivations are illustrated. Afterwards, the stability criterion and controller design approaches under the ADT and MDADT frameworks are explored, which are expressed in the form of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The results of simulations using the switched LPV model of the hypersonic aircraft under the ADT and MDADT switching logics are presented in the section ‘Simulation results’. Conclusions are drawn in the final section.

sec.title: Switched LPV model for a hypersonic aircraft
sec.p: In this section, a switched LPV model for the rigid longitudinal dynamics of a hypersonic aircraft is presented. To be specific, first, we choose the scheduling parameters and divide the scope of the scheduling variables into partitions. Second, in each partition zone, we need to select and calculate the set-point in order to obtain the LPV model of the hypersonic aircraft in this partition. Third, using a Jacobian linearization method and tensor-product (TP) model transformation, we obtain the local polytopic LPV model of each partition zone. Combining all the local LPV models via the switching signal, which is determined by the scheduling parameters, we obtain the overall switched LPV model of the hypersonic aircarft.

The model of the hypersonic aircraft considered in this paper was developed by Bolender and Doman.29,30Figure 1 shows the force distributions of the ideal rigid longitudinal model of the hypersonic aircraft. In Figure 1,

sec.title: Remark 1
sec.p: The polytopic form of the switched LPV model of the hypersonic vehicle is obtained as equation (6) using the TP transformation approach. This method has advantages over other techniques, for example, it can generate different types of convex hulls of the given LPV models and it also can minimize the number of LTI components. Detailed information regarding TP transformations is given in Petres.33

sec.title: Controller design approaches under ADT and MDADT switching logics
sec.p: In this section, the switched controller design methodologies are given for the general switched LPV systems under the frameworks of ADT and MDADT, respectively, which are expressed in the form of LMIs.

sec.title: Remark 2
sec.p:
Definition 1 and Definition 2 are slow-switching logic statements that can be used in the switched system. It is necessary to highlight their differences. Definition 1 means that if a switching signal has the ADT property, the average of the dwell time between any two consecutive switchings is not less than a common constant
τ
a
for all subsystems. However, Definition 2 only requires the average of the dwell time of the
i
th subsystem to satisfy its own
τ
ai
instead of any consecutive subsystem. Therefore, we can conclude that the MDADT switching logic is more flexible than the ADT switching logic in the switching signal design process.

sec.title: Remark 4
sec.p: From the analysis above, the ADT switching logic can be viewed as a special case of the MDADT switching logic. Moreover, compared with ADT switching, it is more flexible in practice to design a MDADT switching to perfect or improve the system performance with fewer constraints, which was thoroughly verified in the simulation part of Zhao et al.28 In practice, it is sometimes too rigid to design a switching logic satisfying ADT. Therefore, the more relaxed and flexible MDADT switching is considerably of importance in engineering implementation.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p:
In this section, based on the presented switched LPV model of the rigid longitudinal dynamics of the hypersonic aircraft and the proposed theorems, simulations were performed to validate the effectiveness of proposed model. The considered flight envelop covered a velocity of
V
H
∈ [ 8000 , 9500 ]
and altitude
h ∈ [ 85000 , 95000 ]
, and the velocity range was divided into three partitions as in Figure 2. The considered trim conditions are listed in Table 1. For the ADT framework,
α
0
= 0 . 1
,
μ = 1 . 01
, and for the MDADT framework,
α = [
0 . 1
0 . 11
0 . 12
]
,
μ = [
1 . 01
1 . 01
1 . 01
]
. By solving the LMIs (23) to (25) and (27) to (29), respectively, we were able to obtain the controller gains. Note that via Theorem 1, for the MDADT case, we have

= 2 . 7763

τ

= 2 . 7763

Then, we performed simulations using the switched LPV model of the hypersonic vehicle under ADT and MDADT switching logics. After obtaining the switched LPV representation of the non-linear hypersonic aircraft, the objective was to track a velocity command. To test the performance of the closed-loop non-linear system of the hypersonic aircraft, the velocity command input shown in Figure 3 was constructed. To fulfill the command tracking and illustrate the effectiveness of the controllers, we used similar techniques to those used in Lu et al.18 In particular, the trajectory of the command was chosen to be a square wave that crosses the three subsystems back and forth with its ADT or MDADT satisfying the requirements of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 (note that this command may seem impractical, but it is complex enough to test our approach, since actually, the switching behaviour is much more smooth than this constructed command signal).

caption.p: Command input for the hypersonic aircraft.

sec.p: Figure 4 shows the non-linear responses of the hypersonic aircraft under the command input. The solid line is the ideal response of the command input. The dashed line represents the output trajectory under the ADT switching logic, and the dotted line shows the velocity response under the MDADT switching logic. Both of the tracking performances are acceptable over the entire time range. However, there is still a difference between the response curves of the two switching logics. From Figure 4, it can be observed that the velocity response of the MDADT switching logic is faster than that of the ADT switching logic, which indicates that the MDADT switching logic outperforms the ADT in achieving the transient performance. Figure 5 shows the altitude tracking responses of the two switching logics. The response under the MDADT framework is better than that under the ADT framework. It should be pointed out that both the tracking responses are acceptable. Figure 6 and Figure 7 display the fuel rate and the actuator inputs, respectively. Note that the control input:fuel ratio and control surface deflection have large peaks when switchings occur, since the command input has a steep change at the point that a switching occurs. It is easy to find that a larger change of command velocity input implies a larger control input.

caption.p: The responses of the system under ADT and MDADT switching logics.
ADT: average dwell time; MDADT: mode-dependent average dwell time.
The altitude response of the system under ADT and MDADT switching logics.
ADT: average dwell time; MDADT: mode-dependent average dwell time.
The fuel rate input under ADT and MDADT switching logics.
ADT: average dwell time; MDADT: mode-dependent average dwell time.
The pitch control surface deflection under ADT and MDADT switching logics.
ADT: average dwell time; MDADT: mode-dependent average dwell time.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper explored the controller design problem for the switched LPV model of a hypersonic aircraft under the frameworks of ADT and MDADT switching logics. Due to the large variation of the parameters, one single linearized model of the hypersonic aircraft seldom guarantees the performance. By Jacobian linearization and TP transformation, the switched LPV model was obtained to cope with this problem. With regard to this switched LPV system, the controller design approaches under both ADT and MDADT switching logics were given through LMIs. By comparison, the MDADT logic is more flexibile than the ADT switching logic. Finally, simulations of the hypersonic aircraft verified the validity and effectiveness of the proposed ADT and MDADT controller design method, respectively, and the merits of the MDADT switching logic. In addition to hypersonic aircraft, the methods proposed in this paper can also be extended to other aircraft such as missile autopilots subject to dramatic parameter variations and a large flight envelope or other systems that can be modelled as switched LPV systems, e.g. active suspension systems.35–37

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
